This Company's system of submarine telegraph

communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often in­different and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should he taken. It costs no more than the indif- ferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best. Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known j Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality?
CITY ANALYST'S LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASGOW, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Cellar Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

div.head: MR. DICEY ON LORD CROMER
div.p: A Cairo contemporary, in a characteristically vigorous leading article, accuses us of a lack of good manners and of honesty in expressing the view that Mr. E. Dicey's recent work entitled "The Egypt of the Future" was in the main a criticism of Lord Cromer. Much as we deplore our contemporary's annoyance we feel unable to withdraw our criticisms ; Mr. Dicey appears to us to hold the view that Lord Cromer has not proved the right man in the right place, and as autocrat of Egypt has not supplied the country with the administrative organisation that it requires. Thia appears to us to be a criticism of Lord Cromer, though our contem- porary may object to the expression, and Lord Cromer is a big enough man to stand criticism. We do not insinuate that Mr. Dicey is inspired- by personal ends. Were he a disappointed, concession-hunter or a mere seeker after sensa­tional news we should have suspected that something less than the welfare of Egypt and- England inspired his criticism. As it is, we have always expressed our belief that his criti- cism Egyptian administration were honest­ly and sincerely made ; but when we are told in effect that he is infallible, we respectfully beg to be allowed to criticise, however much the expression of our views may annoy those friends of a veteran journalist who regard criti­cism of their idol as a species of lèse majesté. We fail to see how Mr. Dicey's sugges­tions are calculated to conduce to the be­nefit of England. We are asked by the veteran publicist to break our promises to France and Egypt, to incur the risk of paying political blackmail to all the Great Powers except Japan and the United States, and of precipitating a European war. Our respect for Mr. Dicey's abilities will not persuade us to throw up our caps at the mention of his suggestions, even though the Editor of our Cairo contemporary begs to be allowed to identify himself with his views.

To return to the question in regard to which we are accused of speaking "like a Government Department." We may begin by pointing out that there are Departments and Departments, and that in some cases it is better to speak like a sensible Government Department than to speak dishonestly or foolishly. We are neither so foolish nor so intellectually dishonest as to believe in the infallibility of Mr. Dicey, how­ever much we admit the clearness of his style and the ability with which he argues a case, based, in our belief, on unsound premises. One of these days we shall doubtless be accused of being lost to all sense of dignity and inde­pendence on the ground that we do not accept the latest ipse dixit of Padgett, M.P., or the newest critic of British rule in Egypt whose views some one of our confrères will doubtless respectfully support; Mr. Dicey, however, should be big enough to stand the criticism which wo have felt it our duty to publish. His thesis is that Egypt is Lord Cromer and all Egyptian Administration to all intents and purposes Lord Cromer's creation. We therefore repeat our statement that Mr Dicey has written his latest book to criticise Lord Cromer, whose administration he does not consider an entire success.

div.head: Plague at Jeddah.
div.p: A telegram from Jeddah reports five deaths from plague there on Monday.

div.head: The Havas Agency.
div.p: According to "Al Moayad," the Egyptian Government has renewed the subvention to the Havas Agency. This is £84 per month.

div.head: Sugar Factory Robbed.
div.p: We hear that the sugar factory at Bibeh has been robbed of a number of copper vats, etc., worth some seven or eight thousand francs.

div.head: Supreme Consular Court.
div.p: Judge Piggott is due in Egypt about the let of March. He will probably proceed first to Cairo, taking any cases there may be in Alexandra afterwards.

div.head: New Alexandrian Paper.
div.p: A new French daily paper is to make its appearance shortly at Alexandria. The capital of the concern is £1,000 and it will be in the name of Paul Manse and Company.

div.head: The Khedivial Ball.
div.p: We have reason to believe that in conse- quence of the death of Prince Ahmed Kamel, the Khedivial hall, which was to have been held at Abdeen Palace on the 28th inst. will be postponed.

div.head: Damanhour Industrial School.
div.p: At a meeting of notables held at the Damanhour moudirieh, under the presidency of the Moudir, in connection with the proposed industrial school, subscriptions aggregating no less than £9,000 were promised in aid of the scheme.

div.head: Storms In the Mediterranean.
div.p: Owing to the bad weather experienced in the Mediterranean, there have been consider able delays in the arrivals of vessels. The Messageries Maritimes S S. Portugal, however, arrived at Alexandria from Marseilles this morning up to time.

div.head: Forthcoming Concert
div.p: The Marquis Filasi and Maestro Kantani, who recently gave such a successful concert at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, a criticism of which appeared in our columns on Friday last, are coming to Alexandria, and intend giving a concert next week.

div.head: Amateur Dramatic Entertainment.
div.p: Owing to unforeseen circumstances it has been found necessary to postpone the dramatic entertainment which was to have been held in Mustapha Theatre on the 21st, 22nd, and 23rd inst, until the 19th, 20th, and 21st March Staff night will be the 2 th March.

div.head: Sudan Medical Department.
div.p: The latest "Sudan Gazette" contains the announcement of the appointment of Mr. J.

div.head: Christopherson. M A.. M D (Cantah), M.R.
div.p: P. (London), F.R C.S (Bug)., Senior Medical Inspector, Sudan Government, as Director of the Sudan Medical Department.

div.head: Little Girl Murdered.
div.p: A native girl of 8 years was found strangled in a street in the Customs quarter on Sunday. The official enquiry showed that the girl had been murdered by some of her relatives who were on bad terms with her mother. The suspected criminals have been arrested.

div.head: Pont Limoun-Matarieh.
div.p: Until further notice the State Railway Administration are running accellerated trains between Pont Limoun and Matarieh and vice- versa, stopping only at Zeitoun and Helmieh. Trains leave Pont Limoun at 4.45 and 5 15 p.m., arriving at Matarieh at 5 and 5.30 p.m. res- pectively. On the return journey they will leave Matarieh at 5.9 and 5.39 p. m., arriving at Pont Limoun at 5.25 and 5.55 respectively

div.head: Maltese Benevolent Society.
div.p: A special performance is to be given at the Zizinia Theatre on Wednesday, 27th inst, in aid of the Maltese Benevolent Society. The performance has been placed under the distin guished patronage of Mr. E B. Gould, I.S.O, H.BM.'s Consul General, and HE the Go vernor has also promised to honour the performance with his pretence. The programme consists of Puccini's evergreen opera "La Bohème." followed by a fantastic ballet by M. Enzo Longhi, entitled "Floréal."

div.head: Prof. Petrie in Durance Vile.
div.p: A comic misadventure to Professor Petrie is reported from Assiout, where the Omdeh, finding a person unknown to him on the ground set aside for the Professor 's excava- tions, seized him and had him thrust into gaol despite his protests that he was the Professor Petrie in question. The Omdeh and the police declared that it "would not wash" and the Professor spent a night in gaol. Such is the story as we heard it—though it is quite possible that the Professor's sojourn in Coles Pasha's hotel may have increased miraculously between Assiout and Alexandria.

div.head: The Creek Schools.
div.p: On Sunday, the feast of the three Greek Orthodox Saints who are the patrons of education was held at the school of the Alexandria Hellenic community. Mgr. Theo- fanis Moschonas, the Metropolitan of Tripoli, represented the Patriarch at the ceremony. The guests were received by Mr. Paleologo Georgia and the professional staff. The president of the Hellenic commnuity, the Hellenic Consul General, and many Ieading Greeks were present. Mr. Georgia made an eloquent speech and suggested that as the community is now giving free meals to he poor pupils, it ought to consider the advisability of building healthy and economical houses for the poorer Greek families.

div.head: EGYPT OF THE FUTURE. "
div.p: CRITICISM IN LONDON
London, Monday.

The general tone of the London Press criticism of Mr. Edward Dicey's work, "The Egypt of the Future," is by no means sympathetic, and his attack on Lord Cromer's policy meets with poor support. "The Globe" says that Mr. Dicey is more successful as a destructive than a constructive critic.
FUNERAL OF PRINCE AHMED
KAMEL.

The fanerai of the late Prince Ahmed Kamel was largely attended, the Pont Limoun station and its neighbourhood being crowded with mourners and sympathisers with the relatives of the deceased. T. H. Princes Mohamed Aly, Hussein Kamel, Said Halim, Ahmed Fouad, Omar and Djemil Toussoun, Abbas Halim Kamel Fezil, Aziz Hassan Kamel ed Din, and Ali Fazil, among other members of the Khédi­vial family, Mustapha Pasha Fehmy and the Ministers, the Governor of Cairo, representatives of the Army of Occupation and the Diplomatic Corps, Mansfield Pasha, Ahmed Jellal ed Din Pasha, and many other distinguished members of native and European Society were there. The coffin, which bore on it the uniform and decorations of the Prince, was carried on a gun carriage drawn by six horses and escorted by a guard of infantrymen of the 3rd and 4th Battalions. artillerymen and sailors, with mounted and foot police. The troops marched with arms reversed, preceded and followed by military bands and pipers, to the family burying-place at Sidi Makuri, near the Citadel, where the deceased had daring his life-time prepared a sumptuous family vault.

The late Prince Ahmed Kamel was the son of H.H. Prince Ahmed Rifaat Pasha, who met bis death in the strange accident at Kafr Zayat in the fifties when a special train contain­ing a number of members of the Khedivial family ran over the swing bridge before the ends had been closed and lucked, and fell into the Nile.
PRINCESS TOUSSOUN FINED.
Princess Toussoun, widow of the late Prince Said Patha Toussoun, of Kent terrace, Regent's Park, was summoned at Marylebone last week on a charge of assaulting Cecilia Jacobsson, her late cook.

The complainant said she had a dispute with the Princess as out a valuable Pomeranian dog, and was accused of stealing it. The Princess struck her several times, pushed her down the corridor to the pantry, at the same rime shaking her. Dr. Powell, who lived in the house, intervened, and a policeman was sent for. The Princess swore. In the end the Princess offered her £2 in settlement, but she refused to accept less than £5, her wages for two months

Giving evidence on her own behalf, the Princess denied accusing the complainant of stealing the dog. The complainant became very excitable, and refused to go to her room, whereupon witness pushed her. She denied striking her, and only used sufficient force to get the cook out of the kitchen.

Mr. Plowden said it was a pity that any mistress in the exercise of her prerogative permitted herself to lay hands upon her servant. The fact was that the Princess lost her temper, and the initial mistake she made was in putting the complainant out of the kitchen. A fine of 10s., with two guineas coats, was imposed.
NATIONALIST DESIDERATA.
Ajax II, in the "Journal du Caire," dis cusses the "desiderata" of certain Nationalists, to which we recently referred, with considerable wit and common sense. We extract the follow­ing passages :---

"One is really touched by the immense and disinterested sollicitude for the interests of the fellah, who, if he ever learns of these controversies, will be doubtless amazed at the gift of utiquity which permits these charming beys and effendis to learn the multiple needs of 9,000.000 souls without going further than the Sphinx Bar and the Ghizeh road."

"One wonders at the variety of the demands that are being formulated—the purest liberal­ism elbows that uncompromising Nationalism that borders on xenophobia. Free trade—plus Protection What charming eclecticism!"

"The first demand is the release of the Denishwai prisoners. In the name of humanity the trial is attacked, and with some cause. But I cannot help feeling that from the point of view of the interests of those unlucky devils six months' sage silence would have bean more valuable "

"After the rights of man, comes the right to ou —free of charge. Commercial chambers are to be formed to regulate the price of commo­dities as is the rule in all parts of Europe! These economic truths are veritable revela­tions... The French revolution lied when it firmed the abolition of all the shackles of human activity, for it is only in Egypt—an African country too—where such transactions are governed by the barbarous laws of supply and demand !"

div.head: THE BRINDISI MAIL.
div.p: NO HOPE OF ACCELERATION.

As our readers are aware, the British Cham ber of Commerce recently approached Lord Cromer with reference to the acceleration of 'he Brindisi mail, suggesting the adoption of the overland route via Alexandria and Suez. Lord Cromer promised to place the matter before the home authorities, but held out little hope of the adoption of the suggestion. His lordship has now replied to the Chamber of Commerce stating that he has "received a despatch from Sir Edward Grey, enclosing copy of a letter from the General Post Office, stating that when the arrange­ments for the Eastern mail service were under discussion not long ago, the question of the Egyptian land route was folly examined in all its aspects, with the result that it was decided not to adopt it, and that there has since been no change which would render necessary any reconsideration of the matter. The invitation for tenders issued last year by the Postmaster General was, therefore, re­stricted to the Canal route, and the offers received for a service by that route are now under discussion."

In acknowledging receipt of Lord Cromer's latter, Mr. H. P. Kingham, president of the Chamber, regrets to note that there is no immediate prospect of reconsideration of the question of the Egyptian land-route in connection with the Eastern mail service. Although their efforts have been unavailing, his committee are very grateful to Lord Cromer for having taken an interest in the matter.

div.head: SINAI.
div.p: Some statements have appeared in the na­tive press to the effect that the territory of Sinai has been annexed to the Sudan and therefore will be under British protection. This is erroneous, and appears to be due to the fact that Sinai is being administered by the Egypt­ian War Office.

div.head: FEIZI PASHA WANTING FUNDS.
div.p: The Constantinople correspondent of the * Journal da Caire" states that Feizi Pasha, who is in command of the forces in Yemen, has threatened to resign unless the 10 batta­lions which he asked for 8 months ago are sent him. The Sultan has accordingly ordered the Treasury to find £T. 50,000 within a fort- night to pay the expenses of the reinforcements, but only half of this sum has been found, and a conflict has arisen between the Ministry of War and the Ministry of Finance. Feizi Pasha is still waiting !

div.head: THE RUSSIAN AFFAIR.
div.p: The Attarin Court of Appeal has confirmed the sentence of two months' imprisonment passed recently by the Native Summary Court on two Greeks and an Armenian who attacked the Russian Consulate in the recent disturb­ances, and reduced to two months the sentence of three months' imprisonment passed on the same accused for assaulting a police officer on duty at the time.

div.head: ANOTHER NEW ISSUE.
div.p: Among forthcoming new issues of capital will be that of the Société Anonyme des Ciments d'Egypte, which will issue 750.000 francs worth of new shares. They will be offered toy public subscription.

div.head: LUZZATO PASHA ON SYRIANS.
div.p: Our Fayoum Correspondent writes : Com- mendatore Luzzato Pasha, general manager of the Bank of Egypt, and Mrs. Luzzato have been staying here tor a few days as guests of Kalid Bey Loutty. They are on their way from Upper Egypt, where the Pasha has been inspecting the different branches of his flourishing bank throughout the country. His Ex­cellency, in the course of an interesting in­terview, which I had with him, informed me that he greatly oommends the Syrians who are employed in hie bank. He told me that he has every confidence in the Syrians, who are, as a rule, an honest race. "Appro­bation from Sir Hubert Stanley is praise indeed," and when Luzzato Pasha praises men for their integrity, his words deserve to be hearkened to, for he knows what he is speak­ing about.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Menepthah sailed yesterday afternoon for Liverpool, via Malta, with pas­sengers, mails, and general cargo.
The Ellerman liner Avon sailed from Malta last evening and is due here on Friday morning next with a general cargo.
The S.S. Roman Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Manchester on the 17th inst, and is due at Alexandria on or about 5th March.

div.head: MILITARY TAILORS.
div.p: EGYPTIAN ARMY OUTFITS A SPECIALITY.
RIDING BREECHES,
F. Phillips & Co.
LADIES' TAILORS.
(high class work only)
CAIRO and ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUEZ.
div.p: FROM CAIRO TO SUEZ BY MOTOR
(From OUR Correspondent.)
Suez, Saturday.

H H. Prince Aziz. in his motor car, accom­panied by two other care, arrived at Suez yesterday afternoon from Cairo by the old mail route. They crossed the desert in six hours, with the exception of one oar, which was delayed owing to a breakdown. Prince Aziz drove down to the docks, and subsequently left for Cairo with his friends by a special train at 8 p.m.

div.head: DEPARTURE OF HODEIDAH.
div.p: The Turkish troopship Hodeidah, whose troops mutinied in the Canal, sailed from Suez last night for Hodeidah. The 17 wounded soldiers, landed at Suez, are now in hospital for treatment.

div.head: STEAMER'S DANGEROUS POSITION.
div.p: The position of the S S. Candleshoe, ashore north of Ashrafi, is reported to be very senous. The vessel is rapidly making water and little hopes of saving her exist, especially if bad weather comes on. A tug with lighters is at present standing by her.

div.head: RETURN OP PILGRIMS.
div.p: Suez, Monday.

The first steamers to return with pilgrims this year are the Khedivial Mail liners Minieh and Mariout The tormer arrived yesterday with 1,400 foreign pilgrims and entered the Canal this day in quarantine, whilst the latter landed Egyptian pilgrims at Suez docks to-day the majority of whom are leaving to night for their respective villages. The health of the pilgrims is satisfactory.

div.head: FOG IMPEDES SHIPPING.
div.p: Again the whole of yesterday, Suez, as well as the Gulf of Suez, experienced a very* thick fog, which lasted for over 12 hours. All steam­ers in the Canal were moored, and no steamer from the South was allowed to enter the Canal till 8 p.m.
The tug Titan, of the Canal Company, had steam up, and was in readiness to proceed wherever she was wanted to assist, bat fortun­ately nothing went wrong in the Canal.
All steamers arriving from the Red Sea were late, owing to their having been obliged to slow down on account of the fog.
This morning, however, the atmosphere is dearer, although doll.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
div.p: La Délégation Municipale s'est réunie le lundi 18 février 1907 a 4 h 1/2 p.m. sous la présidence de S E le Dr. Schiess Pacha.
Présents. MM. Benachi, Mansour Bey Youssef Soliman Soliman Bey Abani, Dr. G. Valensin, mem- bres, I. Sedky Bey, Secrétaire Général.
La Délégation prend note des lettres mi­nisérielles suivantes :

1° Une lettre du 9 février 1907 regrettant de ne pouvoir donner suite à la décision de la Municipalité tendant à la mise en vente, aux prochaines enchères, des terrains dont la pro- prié'é est contestée par le Gouvernement.
2° Une lettre du 12 février 1907 approuvant les crédits votés par la Commission le 30 janvier 1907.
3° Une lettre du 17 février 1907 approuvant les crédits votés par la Commission le 6 ; février 1907.

De l'avis conforme da Conseil du Tanzim, la Délégation 1° accepte la cession de quatre routes à Siouf par la Building Lands, sans aucun engagement de la Municipalité quant à la mise en état actuelle des dites routes. 2* Elle décide en principe la création d'une place devant la mosquée Aboussiri, comptaut sur la Direction Générale des Wakfs pour procéder à des travaux d'embellissement de cette mosquée; 3* elle accepte, sans engagement, la cession d'une bande de terrain pour l'élargissement de la route Bean Séjour.
La Délégation, de l'avis conforme da Comité des plantations, autorise une dépense de L.E. MO environ pour l'achat des bancs nécessaires aux jardins et à divers squares de la ville..
Elle délègue Benachi, assisté de l'Ingé- nieur en Chef, pour assister aux essais qui vont être entrepris par les tramways, pour l'adoption da chasse-corps Tidswell.
Sur la proposition du service sanitaire, la Délégation décide la levée de l'interdiction du commerce des chiffons en ville.

La Délégation adjuge à MM. A. Mayer et Cia. la fourniture des uniformes pour les années 1907, 1908 et 1909, aux prix indiqués dans leur offre, et à M. Kacber, la fourniture de tarbouches, an prix de P.T. 10 1/2-l'an.

La Délégation ajourne pour son examen à une autre séance, une pétition teulent à l'érection sur les quais d'une statue à Alexan­dre le Grand. Le Collège proposera de donner son nom à une place de la ville.
La Délégation renvoie au comité des tra­vaux publies une demande de M. Cosmas poor l'établissement de bains an fort Adda.
Elle accepte une proposition de la police tendant a la création d'une station de voi­tures devant la Savoy Palace Hotel.
La séance est levée a 7 h. 1/2 p.m.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
div.p: "Loreley."

To say there is not a dull moment in Catalani's "Loreley" is not to bestow unstinted praise. Certainly it is a fine work and a grand one, but would be still grander if it were expounded in the same sense of stern simplicity as that in which it is conceived. There is ana bsence of repose and a tendency towards over orchestration (particularly in the first act) which, however stirring, comes at times perilously near the undignified. With all this there are few digressions from the general scheme, which consequently presents no difficulties in bring followed even at a first hearing. The wiles of the "Loreley" are of course too famously portrayed by Heine for ns to attempt, or indeed require, to expatiate thereon. Bat the opera, apparently, shows us the origin of the legend : how the maiden Loreley is betray­ed by one Walter, Sire of the Ober-Wesel ; how, on her having been transformed into a nymph, she frustrates his marriage to Anna VCh Rehberg ; and how she finally lures him to his death. All these incidents, each a tragedy in itself, were brought home, both by composer and exponents, with considerable fervency and power. In the first scene there is a frenzied passage between Loreley and Walter, taken respectively by Signa. Grisi and Sig. Marcolin, and taken, too, very vigorously and convin- cingly. Then comes the metamorphosis, when Loreley as nymph is installed on her deathly rock, "above wonderfully there," as Mark Twain renders it. The scene is not remarkable for lucidity or attraction and we pass on to Act II., which to a great extent is choral ; but it contains several admirable romances, some of which were beautifully rendered by Signa. Finzi, as Anna. Her wedding to Walter is now about to take place, and, as the act proceeds, chorus and orchestra become more and more intense and are worked up to a fine climax, when, by the apparition of Loreley "forbidding the banns," the whole fabric falls with a crash. In Act III, where Walter falls a victim to Lore- ley's wiles, the music, which until now had already shown a marked Wagnerian tendency, becomes a downright, but inadequate, imita­tion. In its insisting reiteration of one motif only, it has a certain resemblance to the Fliegende Holander" and, while the result is very impressive, it is bound to suffer by the comparison. Not only music, bat plot and mounting come under this stricture ; the choice of the plot is in itself not un-Wagnerian, but its presentment has too much of a melo­dramatic trap door and-bogey style. The wood­land path with castle in the background, the bringing in of Anna's bier, the wayside shrine, which in this case is neither useful nor orna­mental, are simply "Tannhauser" "tiré par les cheveux ;" to say nothing of Loreley's (Venus') attempt to compensate Walter (Tann- bauser) fur the death of Anna (Elisabeth , though Tannbauser rejects Venus, while Wal­ter has not the power, even supposing he had the wish, to withstand Loreley's enticement.

But having dwelt on this plagiarism, we have said the worst. The opera is very strong and, brightly given as it was last night, proved most interesting and enjoyable. No small credit is due to Maestro Zuccani's handl­ing of his orchestra and to his skill in keeping them and the chorus well in hand. As we hive said, Signa. Grisi, as Loreley, threw herself vigorously and successfully into the rôle, and Sig. Marcolin, while singing with assiduity, showed at the same time greater dramatic powers than we had believed him capable of. Signa. Finzi handled the part of Anna with expression and refinement The rôle of Her­mann, apparently one of Anna's disappointed lovers, was taken by Sig. Dalbore, but calls for little comment.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H.H. the Duke of Brunswick and his suite, accompanied by Slatin Pasha, have returned to Khartoum from their trip up the White Nile. His Highness is the guest of the Gover­nor General at the Palace.
H.H. the Grand Duke Boris is in Khartoum. He is staying at the Grand Hotel.
The Khedive has conferred the Order of the Osmanieh (3rd class) on Watson Pasha and Hussein Pasha Moharrem, A.D C.'s to His Highness.
Sir Ernest Cassel returned to Cairo yesterday from Assouan and Korn Ombo, and is staying at the Savoy as usual. Mrs. Cassel and Mrs. Ashley will only return at the end of the week.

The latest arrivals at the Savoy Hotel include: -- Comte and Comtesse des lsuard, Mr. and Mrs. R. J. Wilkinson, Justice Bigge, Mme Geo. Zervudachi, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Glazier, Baron de Menasce, Messrs. Urquhart and Martew.

The Savoy Restaurant was quite fall last night with well known diners. Among those giving dinner-parties we noticed : - Sir Ernest Cassel with a party of four. Mr Friedlander had a party of 8. including Mr. and Mrs. Rom, Mr. Gutmann, Mr. and Mrs. Richards. Mr. and Miss Cochrane had a party of 12. Mr. and Mrs. Fowler entertained Mr. and Mrs. Perry, Mr. and Mrs. Foster and Col. Gordon, etc, etc.

Mr. Heston Armstrong, M.P., entertained a party to dinner at the Savoy Restaurant on Sunday evening, the guests including Johnson Pasha, Mrs. and Miss Johnson, Sir James and Miss Blyth, Crookshank Pasha and Mrs Crookshank and Miss Rees.
Comte and Comtesse Baillet Latour enter­tained Count Kodziebrodzky, Comte de Moerkerke, and Lady Vivian.
Mr. Bolonachi had a party of eight, including Mr. and Mrs Michel Salvago, Mrs. George Zervudachi, Mr. Ambroise Zervudachi and Mr. Nicolaides.
Comte and Comtesse de Pourtales have left the Savoy Hotel for Upper Egypt

Major General Sir Charles and Lady Holled Smith, who are at present staying at Shepheard's Hotel, have returned to Egypt after a lapse of many years, during which time Sir Charles has held other important positions in Victoria and South Africa. Entering the Army in 1865 Sir Charles Holled Smith saw active service during the Zulu and Boer wars of 1849 1881, when he was mentioned in despatches He also distinguished himself greatly in the Egyptian War of 1882, when he was again mentioned in despatches,promoted Brevet Major and received the medal with clasp in addition to the Khedive's Star. He was in the Nile Expedition of 1881, gaining farther promotion and men­tion, and also in the Sudan a year later. At Suakin, 1888, he received farther promotion and decoration; and after Tokar, 1891, he was decorated with another clasp, Khedive's Star, and the 2nd class Medjidieh. For four years 1888-1892 he served as Governor of the Red Sea Littoral and Commandant of Suakin ; and in 1892 he was appointed Commandant of the Force in Victoria. He also saw service daring the early months of the late war in South Africa.
Lieut-Col G. R. Atkinson, A.O.D, has been granted leave of absence pending retirement from the Army.

Mr. and Mrs. G. Scott Dalgleish gave a most enjoyable "At Home" at their Ghizeh house on Monday. Cairo Society was right well repre­sented, and an excellent tea added to the success of the Scotch ladies' bind.

The travellers by the train de luxe for Upper Egypt on Sunday night were : Mr. Oberman, Comte Pourtales and party, Comte de Merweldt, Mr. and Mrs. Paull, Mr. E ie Cavadis, Mr. Ghehiadaveson, Mr. Hebb, Mr. Casdaglia, Mr. Lang Anderson, Mrs. Lang Anderson, Mr. Gillson.
We regret to announce the death, which took place at Mansourah yesterday, of Mr. John Venieri.

div.head:
STATE OF PERSIA
QUESTIONS IN PARLIAMENT

div.p: House of Commons.— Mr. Lynch enquired with regard to the parliamentary situation in Persia whether Great Britain was taking steps to promote greater stability of government and to safeguard British subjects. Mr. Runciman replied that the Government desired to abstain from internal interference. Any action would be limited to safeguarding British subjects they were endangered. No danger was anticipated at present. The best prospect of averting interference with foreigners was to make clear to the Persians that we did not intend to interfere in their internal affairs. {Reuter)

div.head:
HOUSE OF LORDS
ITS RIGHT OF VETO

div.p: Dr. MacNamara, speaking at Scunthorpe (?), indicated that the Government would lay on the table a resolution depriving the Lords of the right of veto of a bill which had passed the Commons in two consecutive sessions. He personally believed that before many years there would be no legislators not deriving their commission from the electors. (Reuter)

div.head:
FEHIM PASHA'S FALL
SATISFACTION IN STAMBOUL

div.p: The overthrow of Fehim Pasha, which was done to the strenuous intervention of the German Ambassador, supported by Sir Nicolas O'Conor, has caused universal satisfaction here. His spies and emissaries, through whom he perpetrated crimes of every description have been dispersed. (Reuter)

div.head:
FUNERAL OF CARDUCCI
GREAT NATIONAL GRIEF

div.p: At the funeral of the poet Giosue Carducci unparalleled manifestations of national grief were witnessed. 40,000 people followed The Count of Tofin represented the Royal Family. Several Cabinet Ministers, Senators, and Deputies were present. {Reuter)
The funeral of Carducci was imposing. The Count of Turin represented the King. (Havas)

div.head:
HORRIBLE RAILWAY ACCIDENT
ELECTRIC TRAIN OVERTURNED

div.p: On Saturday four coaches of an electric suburban express, going at seventy miles an hour, mainly occupied by ladies returning from matinees, become derailed and overturned : it dragged for a quarter of a mile on its sides. Twenty-five persons were killed, mostly by falling through the lower windows to the cars and being crushed to pulp between the cars and the earth. Seventy-six were injured. " (Reuter)
The steamship Heliopolis and Ohiauda collided during a storm in, the Bristol Channel. The latter vessel sank. Of a crew of 19, 14 have been drowned. {Reuter)
Banffshire bye-elections. Mr. Waring, Liberal, was elected with 3,901 votes. Mr. Whitelaw, the Conservative candidate, had 1,899 votes. (Reuter)
Eighty students and workmen have been arrested in consequence of a protest against the raids made upon the University. (Havas)

div.head: THE NORDDEUTSCHER LLOYD
A MEMORIAL PAGE TO ITS FIFTY YEARS' JUBILEE
div.p: On the 20th February, 1907, the Norddeutscher Lloyd at Bremen looks back upon a career of 50 years. Its evolution is in the closest way boud with the growth of Germany, with the incraese of German industry, with the progress of techincal art in the construction of vessels and machines. It has transformed the whole world's steamship intercourse, and has knit the four corners of the world into a close unity. Never-ceasing interchange of raw materials and products of industry coupled with the continual passing to and fro of immense numbers of passengers have created a new condition of life.

From small beginnings—one line, of three steamers only, to England, and one to New York—the Norddeutscher Lloyd has never ceased to increase and develop. Fifteen regular Transatlantic lines with twenty branch lines have organised the necessary communications and in addition to this lines between non German countries have ministered in a great measure to the commercial needs of territories still in an undeveloped stage. The Norddeutscher Lloyd's flag is hoisted on 199 steamers ; 417.000,000 marks have poured in the coffers of ship-builders from the N. D. L 6 500,000 passengers have, in the 50 year of its existence, placed it at the head ci al passenger companies. More than 500.100 travellers patronised this company in the year 1905 ; more than 23,000,000 marks a year flow in upon the coal mines through the Norddeutscher Lloyd; more than 14.000,000 marks yearly are spent on its ships for consumption; more than 2,000 agencies, dispersed all over the world, fly the flag of the "Lloyd."

These are proud numbers to be able to set before the world. In the evolution of the 'Lloyd there are three clearly distinguished epoch During the first 20 years, the opening up of traffic with America stands in the fore-rank. The second period, under the managership of J. G. Lohmann, goes from 1877 to his death in 1892. To this period belongs the creation of lines of steamers for the Imperial postal service to Eastern Asia and Australia, and the institution of a series of high-speed steamers to New York. This was something quite new and put the N.D.L. into the highest rank for passenger traffic.

The third great epoch is the present one. It begins by the taking over of the management of the Lloyd by the director general, Dr. Wiegand, in 1892, and may look back open extraordinary successes. Into this period falls the complete transformation, according to modern principles, of the Lloyd's fleet, which has grown to be typical of present-day navigation. From 210.0U0 tons, at the moment of Lohmann's death, the size of the Lloyd's fleet has increased until now it contains 700,000 tons.

Hand in hand with the reformation of the Lloyd's fleet, daring the last period of its history, there went the completion of its different lines ; the doubling of the Imperial postal service ; the development of the net of lines to Eastern Asia and the South Sea by additional lines ; the creation of new communications from Bremen to Central America and the southern parts of North America ; the junction of Japan and Australia : these are the chief facts which make known the increase of the sea traffic of the " N.D.L." during the past 15 years.

A special importance may be attached to the extraordinary business done by the "Lloyd" in the Mediterranean, where many branches are now established. More especially during the last two epochs the traffic to ports on this sea has increased to an enormous extent, not only as the trade, but above all for tourists. When, the year 1886, the first East Asiatic and Australian Imperial postal steamers of the "Norddeutscher Lloyd," which touch also at Genoa and Naples, passed through the Mediterranean, the necessity was felt to introduce a better and more regular service on these waters. More particularly there existed a feeling that a reliable service between these countries and America was absolutely needed. In order to supply this want, the "N.D L" started new line of fast steamers Genoa-Gibraltar New York, in October, 1891, which soon proved a favourite line to the travelling public The Marseilles-Naples-Alexandria line, opened in 1905, met with the same enthusiasm, as it proved to have excellent vessels as well as a most distinguished and well organised body of officers.

In May, 1906, the "Deutsche Mittelmeer Levante Linie," which is run together with the Norddeutscher Lloyd at Bremen and the Deutsche Levante Linie, began its voyages. It unites the West and the East of the Mediterranean. Its vessels go from Marseilles and Genoa via Greece and Asia Minor to the ports of the Black Sea. In order to create a good service between the Near East and Egypt, which latter proved to be the aim of all tourists, the "N.D.L." made an arrangement with the Romanian Line offset steamers 'Serviciul Maritim Roman" in the autumn of 1905 and began a service of fast steamers. Constauza-Constantinople-Smyrns-Alexaindria in the following autumn, thus making it possible to reach Alexandria from Berlin in 4 1/2 days. Besides these lines, which were specially designed for passenger traffic, the "N.D L." started a special line for goods only, Braila-Galatz-Genos, in the autumn of 1905. In this way the Lloyd's flag has, in the lapse of time, become one of the most frequent sights on the Mediterranean. Thousands of travellers who looked for and found health and strength on the blue waves of this sea, thankfully look back to the days they have enjoyed under the protection of this proud banner.

If a shipping company dare say with well justified pride, that it did not only take part in the development of the interests of its Fatherland but that also the interests of the whole world participated to an important and decisive extent in its work ; if a company dare say that the amount and that the moral of material value of the business created by it, during the whole time of its existence, has increased in logical sequence ; if, lastly, it dare claim the glory that the whole steam navigation of the present day own this company its initiations, its progress and its ideas for the creation of new types—to each a company a most considerable international importance may be attached. And this international importance the "Norddeutscher Lloyd" dares claim. It does not only serve trade : it creates it. Wherever sea-going people may meet together under the banner of civilisation, they will offer their heartfelt congratulations to the "Norddeutscher Lloyd'' on the occasion of its 50 years' jubilee.

div.head: THE SUDAN DEVELOPMENT COMPANY
div.p: Mr. Harold J. Hall has moved into the Sudan Development Co.'s new premises in Khedive-avenue, Khartoum. The company's Khartoum office will shortly be re-established in the same building. To facilitate business in addition to the Telephone Exchange, ; company will have a private telephone wire connecting with their works and office at Khartoum North.

We understand that a portion of the river bank in front of the Coptic Church has been reserved as a special landing place for the company's steamers, and that an up to-date floating landing stage is now in course of construction in England.
The company is at present extending their workshops at Khartoum North by the additional of a foundry and also machinery for making iron pipes.

The flour and oil mills at Khartoum North are now in full swing and analysis of the Simsim oil produced proved it to be of the very best quality. Considerable progress has been made at the Khartoum North farm.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY
GOLF AND HELOUAN
PROFESSIONAL MATCH.
div.p: The golfers of Helouan passed their time last week in pleasurable anticipation, as to the probable result of a match which had been arranged to take .place on the Helouan links on Saturday, 16th inst, between the local professional, W. H. Fulford, and J. H. Taylor, the ex open champion of the world, who has been paying a flying visit to Egypt. The residents and visitors took a warm interest in the match and subscribed the handsome sum of twenty five guiness, sixteen being allotted to the first prize and nine to the second.

The game proved to be a most exciting one. Thirty-six holes were played, 18 in the morning and 18 in the afternoon. The result of the morning's play left the players all square, and this state of matters naturally stimulated the excitement of the onlookers as to what the afternoon's play would bring forth. The fact that this was the first time Taylor had handled a club on a desert course, the play on which naturally differs slightly to that on a grass course, seemed to point to there being a consider sider handicap in favour of the local man, but Taylor soon demonstrated that the conclusion was a false one. The match did not terminate until 85 holes had been played, when Fulford was in the proud position of being 2 up and 1 to play. Considering the marvellous way in which Taylor adapted his game to the unusual conditions under which he was playing and Fulford's comparative youth, the loval man is warmly to be congratulared on his success, which would appear to point to a great future for him in the golfing world.

The day was an ideal one for golf : a glorious blue sky overhead with the faintest breeze from the north, enough to temper the heat but not sufficient to interfere with the players. Punctually at 11 a.m. Taylor, who had won the toss, started with a beautiful drive, Fulford with an equally long ball being a little to the left ; two good approach shots landed the balls in the vicinity of the green and the hole was halved in 4. At the second Taylor, slightly pulled his drive, Fulford keeping straight. Taylor duffed his second and placed his third on the green Fulford played a good second and won the hole in 4 to 5, Taylor won the third, making the game all square, but at the fourth Fulford again took the lead, which he increased at the fifth. The next resulted in an excellent half in three. The excitement of the spectators increased as Fulford still further increased his lead at the seventh. The eigth hole- the longest on the course- was halved in a perfect four, bogey for this being six, Taylor making the longest drive of the day. Fulford slightly sliced his drive but recovered wall with his second and by means of getting down a five yard putt, succeeded in halving the hole.

The ninth was won by Taylor, the game standing at the turn two up in Fulford's facour. The tenth saw Fulford's lead reduced, the eleventh was halved, and Taylor securing the twelfth in a brilliant three again put himself on equal terms with his opponent. At the thirteenth Taylor led for the first time, winning by 4 to 5. The sixteenth produced two exquisitie drives, Fulford securing the hole by getting down a four-yard putt. The seventeenth was also won by the young professional, but Taylor, by means of a good three at the eighteenth, succeeded in making the same all square on the first round, the score for the first round being as follows.

The match was resumed at 2.20, the crowd being augmented by many golfers in Cairo. Fulford started favourably by winning the first hole, byt owing to some loose play lost his lead at the second. Taylor somewhat easily won the third. However, Fulford, pulling himself together, took advantage of a bad pull of Taylor's at the fourth tee, securing the hole in 3 to 4, the game then standing all square. For several holes the play now pursued a remarkably even character, the fifth being halved, the sixth won by taylor with a useful three. Fulford retaliating by securing the seventh, also in three. The eigth and ninth were halved. Thus although 27 holes had been played, the players were still on level terms and the excitement amongst the spectators was intense. Fulford started on the homeward journey by winning the tenth, the eleventh, and the celebrated Kyber was halved in a magnificent four. The twelth saw no alteration in the position, each player taking five to hole out. Nothing daunted Taylor deligthed those precent by a full iron shot which landed his ball within three yards of the thirteenth hole, which he easily won.

The game now stood all square with five to play. The fourteenth hole produced a good drive from Taylor, which although a bit sliced was found to be lying clear. Fulford followed by his best drive of the day, which he took advantage of by holing out with a twenty-yard approach putt, this being vigorously applauded. The fifteenth was halved in three and sixteenth was won by Fulford in 3 to 4, he getting down an eight-yard putt ; this bit of work left him dormie two. The seventeenth was halved in five and accordingly. Fulford won a most exciting game. The following is the score of the second round : -

It will be notived that neither player succeeded in lowering the record for the course, which stands at 69 annd was accomplished by Fulford early this seasona remarkable performance considering Bogey is 80.

div.head: FINAL LADIES' NOMINATION POLO TOURNAMENT.
div.p: The gathering to witness the finals of this tournament was the largest we have seen on the K.S.C. grounds this year. Teams left in for the finals were as follows :
The Whites eventually won on their combination, but the game was keen and exciting throughout.
First Chukker.- The Reds were the first to score, somewhat luckily, as the Whites, in defending, his between their own goal posts. But the score was shortly brought to one all.
Second Chukker.- The Whites added 2 goals to their score from the result of some good combined play on the part of Major Patterson and Mr. Bowen.
Third Chukker.- The game was very level, Capt. Rome having bad luck not to score.
Fourth Chukker.- The Whites added one more to their score and so won a very interesting tournament, by 4 goals to 1.

div.head: SUBALTERNS' CUP.
div.p: The first tie in the Subalterns' Cup was played off between the King's Own Scottish Borderers and the Coldstream Guards Team III. The K.O.S.B. won by 6 to 1 a keenly contested, if somewhat erratic, match. This is the K.O.S.B.'s first appearance in this field, and we congratulate them on their success.
The cup for this tournament is very sportingly presented by the Coldstream Guards.
Seven teams have entered, three from the Guards, two from the Inniskilling Dragoons, one from the K.O.S.B., and one from the "Greenjackets."

In the tie played off yesterday, between the Inniskilling Dragoons' 1st team and the King's Own Scottish Borderers, the Dragoons were too strong and won somewhat easily by 8 goals to 2. The Borderers, however, played up well, and considering the very sharetime they have been playing polo, gave a very creditable display.
The second match - Inniskilling Dragoons' 2nd team versus Coldstream Guards' 1st term- fell through, owing to the illness of one of the Dragoons' team.

div.head: DR. WIlLIAMS' PINK PILLS
div.p: "I'm always 'on the go' from morning till night," said Mrs. Wright, of 26, Quay-street, Manchester, greatly respected by travellers and theatrical companies as a kindly landlady. "But," she continued, 'twelve months ago I overtaxed my strength, and a severe illness followed- the development of which threatened to be even more serious. Fortunately, I turned to Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People for a cure, and I have them to thank for the good health I can now boast of.

"Yes," said Mrs. Wright, "if you had seen me then you would not have recognised me. I was a complete wreck, languid, run down, and without an atom of energy. At the same time I caught a severe cold, and in my weak state it played havoc with my constitution. I suffered from headaches, and the pains across my eyes and foreheard were so severe at times that I could not lift my head. If I did I became dizzy, and a sickly sensation would overcome me. My tongue was thickly coated, and my limbs seemed to drag like lumps of lead.

"Going upstairs I became exhausted and breathless long before reaching the top, with sharp stabbing pains in my chest and back. Then I had to stop, panting until I could regain breath. My nerves were completely unstrung ; I seemed to have
No Control over My Hands

and they trembled violently. During long sleepless nights my illness preyed upon my mind, and in the morning I felt more tired than at bedtime. I was so terribly weak I could only just crawl out of bed; sometimes it took me hours to dress.

"Things went from bad to worse, and I felt more dead than alive. I had no appetitie and was restless and irritable. I tried all sorts of medicine in my endeabour to get better, but without the slightest good. Day by day aI lost weight until I became
Terribly Weak and Reduced

"When I was beginning to despair of things ever mending one of my visitors remarked, Why don't you try Dr. Williams' Pink Pills?" So I then and there-decided to give these pills a trial. After taking them for some time my hopes were raised, for I could enjoy food without fear of indigestion. Thus encouraged, I continued with Dr. Williams' Pink Pills, and each dose seemed to bring back my lost energy. So I steadily improved until now I am no longer troubled with headaches ; I sleep well at night, and wake in the morning refreshed and ready for my day's work. My nerves are strong, and I seem to be endowed with
New Strength and Energy
I am now 65 years of age, strong, hearty, and can get about much better than most women of my age. Dr. Williams' Pink Pills put new blood into m veins, and saved me months of suffering."

Dr. Williams' Pink Pills give real help to all who are weak or overwrought by reason of the Rich Good Blood that they actually make in abundance. Common pills coloured pink can never cure you ; only Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People (full name on every box) make ne, good blood, and cure Anaemia, Weakness, Indigestion, Exzema, Rheumatism, Sciatica, St. Vitus' Dance, Neuralgia, Nervous Disorders, and Ladies' Ailments.
Sold by all chemists and druggists at P.T. 14 the box and P.T. 70 for six boxes.

div.head: Capital . . . £500,625
div.p: 2,000 Ordinary Shares have been subscribed for by the Signatories to the Memorandum of Association.

81,300 Ordinary Shares are reserved for subscription by the Directors and their friends. 3,332 Founders' Shares are reserved for subscription by the Signatories to the Memorandum of Association who are Directors and their friends at the rate of one Founders' Share for every 25 of the above-mentioned 2,000 and 81,300 Ordinary Shares.
(A similar right is given by this Prospectus to applicants for multiples of 25 Ordinary Shares

7,500 Founders' Share are reserved for subscription by the Directors and their friends, who have arranged for the subscription of the whole of the Capital of the Company. The Memorandum and Articles of Association provide that the profits of the Company which it shall from time to time be determined to distribute in respect of any year or other period, shall be applied in order of priority and manner following, that is to say :—
FIRST, as to 5 per cent, thereof to payment into the Company's,reserve fund.
SECONDLY, to the payment of a dividend at the rate of 6 per cent, per annum on the capital for the time being paid up on the Ordinary Shares.
THIRDLY, 10 per cent of the residue of such profits shall be paid to the Directors, as, and by way of, additional remuneration for their services.
FOURTHLY, the residue of such profits shall be divided as to 60 per cent thereof among the holders of the ordinary Shares; and as to 40 per cent, thereof among the holders of the Founders' Shares.

and that in the winding-up of the Company the surplus assets which may be distributable among the Members, shall as to 60 per cent, thereof be divided amongst the holders of the Ordinary Shares, and as to the remaining 40 per cent, thereof, among the holders of the Founders' Shares.
41,700 of the Ordinary Shares and the remainder of the Founders' Shares, viz., 1,668.
are now offered for Subscription in the following manner:
Allotments will only be made to applicants of multiples of 25 Ordinary Shares, each 25 Shares entitling the applicant to subscribe for one Founders' Share.
The Ordinary Shares are payable as follows :
10s. per Share on Allotment
£1 two months after Allotment ;
And the balance in Calls not exceeding £l per Share at intervals of not lens than two months from the date of the last preceding Call.
1st per Share (being payment in full on the Founders' Shares) must be paid on Application.

The minimum subscription upon which the Company may proceed to allotment is fixed by the Articles of Association at 10 percent, of the Shares offered to the public for subscription, but the Directors will proceed to allotment of the whole of the Capital of the Company, the subscription of which has been arranged. Subscribers may on payment in full on the Ordinary Shares allotted to them, receive, at their own cost, Share Warrants to bearer in respect of each allotment if declared.

div.head: PROSPECTUS
div.p: The primary objects of the Company are to establish a bank for discount, to make advances on securities or shares or to carry them over, and general banking purposes, to take securities for safe custody, to make issues of Egyptian and other companies either on its own account or for others, and to carry on a general financial and trust business for investment of capital in Egypt and the Sudan.
It is acknowledged that a bank of this description will supply an important want, the need of an institution such as this having often been proved.

div.head: MANAGEMENT
div.p: The Directors have been connected with Egypt for many years, and they are confident that there is an immense field available for remunerative trade and industry They look for a considerable expansion of business relationships between Egypt and other countries, and having regard to the.time and political situation and the period of prosperity through which Egypt is passing, they are of opinion that the present is propitious, and they anticipate a successful and remunerative career for this Company, and they have great reliance in the personality of the Manager, who is well known and esteemed in financial circles and whose business relationship and experience is sufficient to warrant a firm and intelligent management.

The Directors and their friends thoroughly believe in the future prosperity of the Company, and accordingly have arranged to themselves subscribe for 81,300 Ordinary Shares, and to take up the whole of this issue without commission.
The Articles of Association provide as follows :
The qualification of every Director shall be the holding of Shares or Share Warrants to Bearer of the Company of the nominal value of not less than £1,000.

That each of the Directors, other than the Chairman, shall be paid out of the funds of the Company by way of remuneration for his services, a salary at the rate of £100 per annum, and the Chairman shall be paid a salary at the rate of £200 per annum. The Directors shall also be entitled to the share of the profits under Clause 6 of the Memorandum of Association (mentioned on the first page of this Prospectus), and the same shall be divided among the Directors in such proportions and manner as they by agreement may determine, and in default of such Agreement equally.

If any director, being willing, shall be called upon to or shall perform and extra services, or shall make any special exertions in going or residing out of the country where he usually resides or otherwise, or any of the purposes of the Company, the Company shall remunerate the Director either by a fixed sum or by percentage of profits or otherwise as may be determined by the Direcotrs, and such remuneration may be either in addition to, or in substitution for his share in the remuneration above provided.

The Directors may from time to time appoint one or more of their body to be Managing Director or Managing Directors of the Company, either for a fixed term or without any limitation as to the period for which he or they is or are to hold office, and may, from time to time, remove or dismiss him or them from office, and appoint another or others in his or their place or places. The remuneration of a Managing Director shall from time to time be fixed by the Directors or by the Company in General Meeting, and may be by way of salary or commission or participation in profits, or by any or all of those modes.

The estimated amount of the preliminary expenses connected with and incidental to the formation of the Company and the issue of this Prospectus, including Solicitors' charges, registration fees, advertising, printing, postages, office expenses, etc., is £4000.
There are no Contracts.
A copy of the Memorandum of Association, with the names, addresses, and descriptions of the signatories thereto, is printed in the fold, and forms part of this Prospectus.
It is intended to apply, in due course, for an official quotation and settlement of the above Shares on the London Stock Exchange.

Applications for the Shares should be made on the accompanying forms, and sent together with the necessary deposit, to the Bankers of the Company, crossed to the account where the number of Shares allotted is less than the number applied for, the surplus money paid on application will be credited towards the amount payable on allotment, and any balance will be returned.
Failure to pay allotment money or any installment on the Shares allotted at the times fixed will render the amount paid liable to forfeiture.
Copies of the Memorandum and the Articles of Association can be inspected at the Cairo offices of the Company at any time during business hours whilst the list remains open.

div.head: Egyptian Salt and Soda Coy., Ltd.
div.p: The Directors of the Egyptian Salt and Soda Company, Ltd, have decided to issue at par 50,000 new ordinary shares of £1 (one pound sterling) each to rank pari passu with existing ordinary shares. The new shares are now offered by preference to Holders of the 450,000 existing ordinary shares, and will be allotted to applicants in the proportion of one new share for every complete nine old shares. Forms of application can be obtained from the Company's Bankers, the National Bank of Egypt, in Cairo, Alexandria, or London.

Holders of share warrants to bearer wishing to exercise their right to subscribe must present their warrants to the Company's Bankers for verification and stamping from the 18th to 20th February 1907 together with applications for the new shares and the sum of 10 (ten shillings) per share applied for. The Balance of 10/ (ten shillings) per share must be paid on or before 20th March 1907. Share Warrants to bearer will be issued to Allottees in respect to fully-paid shares upon application, and payment of stamp duties.
Registered Share Holders should make spplication direct to the Secretary at the Registered Office of the Company, 6 Old Jewsy, London, E.C.

Applications for the new shares must be received by the Company's Bankers or by the Company itself, as the case may be not later than 20th February 1907, after which date the Directors will allot any new shares not applied for, to such persons as they may deem fit. 29587-9-7

div.head: Khedivial Mail Line
div.p: The new 18-knot twin crew S.S. "Osmanieh," leaving Alexandria on February 28th, March 14th and 28th, and April llth, will follow a special fast itinerary, reaching Piraeus (Athens) in 30 hours, Smyrna in 47 hours, and Constantinople in 74 h hours, in connection with the Oriental Railways daily express service for Vienna, Berlin, Paris and London.
Special arrangements will be made for part of the 7.30 am. Express train from Cairo to run direct alongside.

This vessel is most luxuriously appointed, with accommodation (mostly in 2-berth cabins on deck) for 149 first class amidships and 70 second class alt. Her public saloons are exceptionally spacious and attractive, and she is also fitted with 8 large cabines de luxe on the spar deck, and an "Imperial" private suite on the promenade deck comprising sitting-room, lounge, bedroom, 2 cabins, bath room, lavatory, etc., with private promenade deck above.

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie
SERVICE DES RECETTES
AVIS
div.p: M.M. les proprietaires d'immeubles batis situes a Alexandrie et dans sa banlieuem sont informes que, en execution de l'art. Il du Decret du 13 Mars 1884, les roles d'imposition pour l'exercise 1907 dresses en vertu et en conformite des Decrets du 13 Mars 1884 et 11 Avril 1886, ont ete arretes en rendus executoires a partir du 15 Fevrier 1907.

Les roles d'imposition comprennent les constructions imposees en 1899 et dont les huit annees sont revolues ainsi que celles nouvellement construites et acheeves en 1906 ; ces roles sont deposes a la Municipalite au Service des Recettes, ou les proprietaires pouront en prendre connaissance.

Les roles d'imposition sont mis en recouvrement et chaque contribuable doit payer le contant de l'impot dont il est redevable, sous peine d'y-etre contraint, en conformite de l'article 14 du Decret du 13 Mars 1884.

L'impot est payable par trimestre d'avance contre des recus emanants du Service des Recettes portant le cachet du Directeur du Service et la signature du percepteur charge du recouvrement pour chaque immeuble separement.

Les reclamations a formuler devant le Conseil de revision contre les operations du recenseurent devront etre presentees jusqu'au 14 Mai 1907 pour les prorietes dont les huit ans sont revolus et 14 Aout 1907 pour les constructions nouvelles.
Le Vice President,
29570 4-3 signe: DR. SCHIESS.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui a midi et demie.)

Les affaires au comptant sont a peu pres nulles. On ne traite guere que pour fin et encore dans des proportions restreintes ; les nouvelles emissions pour lesquelles il n'y a rien a verser ont naturellement la preference d'une speculation aux abois.

Nombre de titres sont en baisse : la Delta Light tombe a 11 1/2, l'Obligation Credit Foncier a 342 l'ancienne et 271 1/2 la nouvelle, les Nungovich Hotels a 29 1/2, la Cassa di Sconto a 275 l'ancienne et 269 la nouvelle, l'Urbaine a 7 3/8, le Comptoir a 7 1/4 la nouvelle, la Building a 5 13/16, l'Union Fonciere a 6 1/8, et le Credit Franco-Egyptien a 6 2/16.

Parmi les nouvelles emissions, l'United s'inscrit a 1 7/32 l'action et 10 la fondateur, la Karam a 15/16, la Levico a 1 3/16 l'action et 15 la fondateur, l'Arditi a 1 9/32 l'action et 23 la fondateur.
Il n'est pas possible de dire de facon certaine si la faiblesse s'accentuera encore, mais il est vraisemblable que nous touchons a la fin de la crise.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le taux de l'escompte libre a Londres est toujours renseigne a 4 3/4 pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolide anglais est reste avant hier invarie a 87, de meme que l'Unifee a 102 3/4 et les autres valeurs egyptiennes a leurs prix precedents. Seule la Delta Light a retrograde de 1/8 a 11 3/4.
A Paris, le Credit Fonciere Egyptien a hausse de 5 fancs a 780. La Banque d'Athenes est demeures inchangee a 135.

Ici, le marche a presente, ce matin, le meme aspect placide que samedi passe, a ceci pres qu'on a observe un tantinet d'activite et d'amelioration, en ce sens du moins que les offres trouvaient plys aisement une contrepatie. A noter aussi un bon mouvement sur les Nungovich, les Entreprises Immobilieres et les Express Nile.
Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National, delaissee, s'est tassee a 28 1/16, de meme que l'Agricole a 9 13/16-7/8. Les part de Fondateur Comptoir Financier a progresse a 9 3/8.

Le Credit Foncier a avance a 774. La Daira s'est raffermie a 17 3/8. La part de fondateur Warden Estate a flechi a 8 1/2 et celle de l'Immobiliere a 700. L'Union Fonciere a retrograde a 6 1/8 3/16. L'Allotment s'est encore alourdi a 3 1/4 ; sa part s'est, par contre, inscrite a 128.
Les Enterprises Immobilieres et Travaux ont atteint L.E. 11 pour terminer a 10 5/8 11/16 ; leur part a avance a P.E. 245. L'Epargne Immobiliere a cloture a 3 3/16 ; se part est remontes a 217.
En tres bonne demande, l'Express Nile a avance a 6 3/4, acheteurs; sa part a fini a 325.
La Delta Light a faibli a 11 9/16. Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire ont molli a 284. Les Ciments ont ete cotes 54.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hotelieres, les Nungovich, bien disposes, ont avance a 30. Les Upper Egypt se sont raffermis a 4 7/8.
Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land a ete ramassee a 4 1/4-5/16. Les Markets ont faibli a 29 sh. Les Salt and Soda ont progresse a 22 sh. 6 et les New Egyptian a 20 sh. 7 1/2.

Nous avons deja expose les conditions de la souscription aux 15,0 0 actions nouvelles de l'Express Nile Steamers Co., souscription qui sera ouverte apres-demain, aux guichets de MM.H. de Vries et Boutigny au Caire, pour etre close samedi prochain 23 Fevrier.

Rappelons que ces actions, d'une valeur nominale de L.E. 4 sont emises au taux de L.E. 5, soit avec une prime de L.E. 1, dont le montant sera integralement porte a la reserve. Il est reserve aux detenteurs actuels un droit de preference a la souscription a raison de deux actions nouvelles pour une ancienne. Les actions non souscrites par les proprietaires d'actions existantes seront reparitee parmi les autres souscripteurs.

On voit des lors les avantages exceptionne's que cette emission presente pour les porteurs actuels, aussi bien que pour les souscripteurs ordinares, le cours actuel du titre etant de plus de L.E. 6 1/2 et promettant d'atteindre a bref delai un prix plus eleve. On s'attend, on effet, au cours de L.E. 8 d'ici quelques jours, ce quie constituers une difference de L.E. 3. Or donc, comme les porteurs actuels ont droit a 2 actions nouvelles pour une ancienne, il on resulters pour aux un, benefice d'environ L.E. 6 s'ils usent de leur droit de preference, et ce avec un debours de L.E. par action, c'est-a-dire P.E. 50 a la souscription et P.E. 50 a la repartition.

En dehors de cet avantage financier d'ordre immediat, il y a lieu de prendre en consideration que l'enterprise de la Nile Express Steamers Co. est par elle meme excellente et d'un avenir brillant. Les resultats qu'elle a deja donnes ont ete remarquablement satisfaisants. Ils ont meme depasse toutes les esperances, car avec un premier captial minime, la Societe a reussi, en un court laps de temps, a organiser un service de voyageurs et un serice de marchandises qui fonctionnent a souhait. Or, l'augmentation du capital social permettra de donner a ces deux branches, au service des marchandises notamment, une extension appele a rapportere des benefices considerables en presence des avantages incontestables que le transport par la voie du Nil offre de plus en plus au commerce. Cl'est, du rest ,pour repondre specialement a ces desidera auxquels elle ne pouvait guere asti-faire avec un mate riel insufficient, que la Societe a recon d'augmenter sa flottile, de maniere a faire face a toutes les demandes des negociants. comme on le voit, l'affaire repond a un besoin public qui s'accroltra avec l'extension que prendre necessairement la navigation fluviale par suite du developpement croissant des affaries. "

Les renseiguements que nous avons donnes avant=hier sur la Delta Land Co. sont confirmes de source officielle. Le Board de Londres de cette Societe disparait pour faire place au nouveau conseil d'administration dont nous avons fait connatire la composition et qui aura son siege au Caire.

En outre, les administrateurs de la Delta Land on approuve la decision prise par la Delta Light Railways Co. a l'effet que les interets communs des deux Societes soient de nouveau unis dans les conditions arretees lors de la formation de la Delta Land.
Cette resolution ne pourra, naturellement, devenir definitive que lorsqu'elle aura ete ratifee par les actionnaires reunis en assemblee generale.

div.head: DECES
div.p: Nous avons le regret d'annoncer la mort de Madame Veuve Nouzha Dibo , nee Hakim, survenue hier soir a 7. h. 1/2. La detunte etail la mere de M. Andre Dibo, le distingue secretaire general de la Bourse Khediviale d'Alexandrie. Nous addressons au fils et a la famille, que cette mort vient d'eprouver si cruellement, nos plus sinceres condoleances.
Le convoi funebre partira cet apres-midi a 3 heures 1/2 de la maison mortuaire rue Salah-el-Dine N. 37 pour serendre a l'Eglise Syrienne Orthodoxe.

div.head: To the Printers of Egypt
div.p: SALISBURY SQUARE
FELLT STREET. LONDON. E.C.
Gentlemen,

TEN years ago we established in London the CAXTON TYPE FOUNDRY to manufacture Printing Types on the interchangeable time and labor-saving principles of Standard Point Line, and Point Set on Point Body. We claimed, and have established in the statement, that the exclusive use of Caxton Printing Types would save one-fourth of the compositors' time in the setting of all kinds of hand composition. At the present time over 10,000 Printers in the United Kingdom, Australia, Canada, Africa, the Indian Empire, and other British possessions are customers of the Caxton Type Foundry.
As is well known, the type of industry of America is controlled by a type TRUST, and in the United Kingdom by a similar organization known as the type RING of British Type Manufacturers.

The CAXTON TYPE FOUNDRY was founded to oppose all such combinations. It is independent of all such connections, and is therefore, selling type at a lower price, and furthermore, guarantees to sell at the same price in all parts of the British Empire.

Another branch is the CAXTON WOOD MILLS, the largest and most complete Wood Working Plant in the British Empire, exclusively employed in the production of space and labour-saving woodwork for Printers. We have made a speciality of using hard wood exclusively in all your productions. Wood Furniture and Reglet is made out of Tungstone, a specially close-grained Wood which is so heavy that it sinks in water and is therefore particularly valuable.

We are also makers of the widest and most complete range of PLATEN PRESSES in the World, comprising the well-known "Caxton" Platen, for fine work : the light-running "Swift" Platen for small printers : the Haddon "Improved Godon," suitable for any jobbing printer : the Haddon "Safety Platen," capable of printing 2,500 full formes per hour : the Haddon "Improved Victoria," modelled on the Cropper principle, but superior in construction and output.
We invite enquiries, when complete Catalogues with all details will be sent post free.
Yours faithfully,
JOHN HADDON & CO.
Agent for Egypt: JEFFREY W. EADY
Chareh Momtaz, Boulevard Mohamed Aly, Cairo.

div.head: FRESKEL.
div.p: WHAT IT IS
FRESKEL is a dry powdered preparation for Wall and Ceiling Decoration, made ready for use with the addition of water.
It is easily prepared and applied.
WHAT IT DOES
FRESKEL, covers well, and works easy Does not crack, peel, or show brush marks. Does not rub off.
ECONOMICAL - EFFECTIVE.
